It's disturbing to watch, and when you see that there's 10,700 subscribers on her account.  Now, any of the players that are involved, none of these people even care.  I mean, these are people that are more likely living in basements.  They haven't gotten out very much in life.  They're kind of stuck in front of a computer.

This is Susan Bassey, and this is Santa Clara County Sheriff's Deputy Officer Gomez.  He broke my hand and violated my civil rights in that courthouse right behind him, and that has resulted in a federal lawsuit that the county is working very hard to make sure they don't have to pay out on.  But my job on this day, six months later, was to record officer gomez and the other sheriff's deputies to see if they were willing to violate civil rights of other people including my associates because if they
were

that would be a pattern in practice of violating state and federal law.  that would be something that would come under the jurisdiction of the california attorney general and it was recently announced that the attorney general will be investigating the l?  a sheriff's department when we in fact know that law enforcement agencies all over California are violating people's civil rights.  This is law-abiding activity.  This is my First Amendment right to speak up against my government.  It is not your opportunity to harass me, to intimidate me, to trust me, to hurt me.  We will not take your information.  Long before I was aware there were people filming the police and putting the videos up on YouTube, I made this video.  There were a group of protesters, about 20, across the street from this family courthouse.  And yet there were several police officers who were gloving up.  And this is Officer Ray.  He was on the phone with what appeared to be a judge who was giving him orders that made him vastly uncomfortable.  We are doing nothing wrong.  It violates our First Amendment right.  You must read the U.S.  Constitution.  You must read the California Constitution.  This is law of violent activity.  Pastor Gomez, great, how are you?  I'm good, thank you.  From public records requests that I had made of the courthouse, I knew that the judges and the lawyers inside that courthouse were very upset about people protesting outside the courthouse.  It was bad for business when people talked about judges taking their children or ordering them to pay too much child support.  But the crowd was not threatening, and it had been moved across the street.  Abide by the order.  I am on a city sidewalk.  I will continue to protest family court.  I am not doing anything wrong.  Officer Ray had in his hand an order that said that nobody would be permitted to protest on the sidewalk outside that courthouse.  When those police officers left that courthouse and walked onto the sidewalk, they left their jurisdiction, meaning that it would be the San Jose Police Department that would be required to make the arrest.  But police officers know that they are not allowed to make arrests on unconstitutional orders.  And that is perhaps why Officer Ray was so concerned.  He didn't immediately arrest the protester.  He continued to pace back and forth.  He continued to watch him.  They followed him, three police officers, far more than we ever saw on any protester at the U.S.  Capitol. They were not interested in arresting the other protesters, only my associate.  These people had been out there protesting the family courts. They violated the oath, they violated their training, and they violated the Constitution in order to enforce a single order issued by a judge who didn't want us talking about what was going on inside that courthouse.  and i could tell by the look on officer gomez's face he was very uncomfortable.  he was violating somebody's civil rights for a second time and this time it wasn't me but it was my associate.  all of those video cameras and body cams were picking up what the police officers were saying and my associate was prosecuted for nearly a year.  i got the police reports because he's also a witness on the day that officer gomez violated my civil rights and the district attorney decided to prosecute me instead.  but what i didn't get was those body cams.  So after a year, I finally decided to produce my videos to my associate's criminal defense attorney, and the criminal charges against him were immediately dismissed.  And it was at that point that he had a civil rights claim against the county as well.
